t: The*p oracle concerning Damascus. “Behold,*pn Damascus is about to be removed from being a city And*ln will become a fallen ruin.
The*ln cities of Aroer are forsaken; They*ln will be for flocks to lie down in, And*ln there will be no one to frighten them.*i
The*ln fortified city will disappear from Ephraim, And*ln sovereignty from Damascus And*ln the remnant of Aram; They*ln will be like the glory of the sons of Israel,” Declares*ln the Lord*s of hosts.
Now*ln in that day the glory of Jacob will fade, And*ln the fatness of his flesh will become lean.
It*ln will be even like the reaper gathering the standing grain, As*ln his arm harvests the ears, Or*ln it will be like one gleaning ears of grain In*ln the valley of Rephaim.

Yet*ln gleanings will be left in it like the shaking of an olive tree, Two*ln or*i three olives on the topmost bough, Four*ln or*i five on the branches of a fruitful tree, Declares*ln the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
In*ln that day man will have regard for his Maker And*ln his eyes will look to the Holy One of Israel.
He*ln will not have regard for the altars, the work of his hands, Nor*ln will he look to that which his fingers have made, Even*ln the Asherim and incense stands.
In*ln that day their strong cities will be like forsaken places in the forest, Or*ln like branches which they abandoned before the sons of Israel; And*ln the land will be a desolation.
For*ln you have forgotten the God of your salvation And*ln have not remembered the rock of your refuge. Therefore*ln you plant delightful plants And*ln set them with vine slips of a strange god.*i
In*ln the day that you plant it*i you carefully fence it*i in, And*ln in the morning you bring your seed to blossom; But*iln the harvest will be*i a heap In*ln a day of sickliness and incurable pain.
Alas,*ln the uproar of many peoples Who*ln roar like the roaring of the seas, And*ln the rumbling of nations Who*ln rush on like the rumbling of mighty waters!

The*ln nations rumble on like the rumbling of many waters, But*ln He will rebuke them and they will flee far away, And*ln be chased like chaff in the mountains before the wind, Or*ln like whirling dust before a gale.
At*ln evening time, behold, there*i is*i terror! Before*ln morning they are no more. Such*ln will*i be*i the portion of those who plunder us And*ln the lot of those who pillage us.
